Intense, eh?!!..you may ask.Nah, on the contrary, Deadly Illusions is like those typical B movies of Hollywood watched largely for guilt pleasure than anything else. The plot is unreal, the twists are laden with glaring loopholes and the climax (or anti-climax if you could call it that) is a huge let down with some unanswered questions. Sad to say this as there was a good concept here which got mauled and killed by inept execution.As for the ever charming Kristin, her performance is the best of the lot and you will actually sit through this muddle of a movie only if you love her. I was intrigued to watch this movie because I'm an author and author coach. It's a psychological, erotic thriller that is so badly executed that I'm giving you fair warning here.THINGS I LIKED:
Fans of Sex and the City will be excited to see Kristin Davis starring in a feature film. Unfortunately, she's not a strong enough actress to save this film. Her character is conflicted in many ways. I thought it was sweet that, as a mom, she had different handshakes to say goodbye to each of her kids when she dropped them off at school.Greer Grammer stars in the movie and also produces it.I liked the original musical soundtrack by Drum & Lace.Every author's writing process is different. In the movie, we see Kristen Davis' character writing her book with pen and paper, rather than on a computer. I have some author clients who do that. We also see her create a storyboard on a big board, a technique I recommend to my clients because it really helps you "see" the story develop and allows you to be very intentional where you place certain scenes.Husbands and wives need to be extremely careful in order to protect their marriage from external relationships and impropriety. For example, my husband NEVER drove home our female babysitters. It wasn't that I didn't trust him or our sweet babysitters. Too many crazy things can happen based on what other people think could have happened, you know? It's just not worth it. No, people shouldn't assume or judge, yet they do.THINGS I DIDN'T LIKE:
Even the title isn't original. So many books have been written with the same name.I'm surprised that Dermot Mulroney went for this script.Weird and creepy. Review title: Leaves too much open to interpretation, thus losing the plot
Review_body: Deadly Illusions starts off on a high note with Mary Morrison (Kristin Davis), a successful bestselling author looking for a caregiver for her two children while she reserves her time for a new novel, with a lucrative offer on the cards. She announces that when she writes, she transforms into someone she herself cannot control, and therefore without a nanny, her children will face neglect. Her husband Tom (Dermot Mulroney) is a busy executive too, and both are delighted with Grace (Greer Grammer), a young girl who opts for the job and is an instant hit with the kids.Grace however, is more than a handful as she starts to take control over the household, enters a passionate and steamy relationship with Mary and even seduces Tom. The sudden murder of Elaine, Mary's closest friend, suddenly wakes Mary out of her stupor as Grace is a suspect. Mary soon discovers that Grace wasn't sent by the agency she had contracted for hiring the nanny and that she is a known patient of split personality and bipolar disorder. In the meanwhile, Grace attacks Tom viciously at home and leaves him bleeding profusely. Mary is able to save Tom, but Grace is sent to a mental rehabilitation center that Mary visits often. She is also able to complete her new novel that she dedicates to Elaine, whose murder remains shrouded in mystery.Deadly Illusions meanders midway and loses direction completely before pressing the accelerator again towards the finishing line rather abruptly. It leaves many loose ends in need of being tied and also has a rather underwhelming climax, open to interpretation much more than anticipated. As such, it is a rather insipid outing with oodles of opportunities lost in the procedure. Performances are listless too, as no sympathy gathers for anyone concerned.

Review title: Why did these actors do this project?
Review_body: This is a miserable failure. The only two reasons I think Dulmot Mulroney. Kristin Davis and Shanola Hampton would have ever done this is either they loved the idea of duality in horror (who doesn't?) or they made some pact with the devil in exchange for their talents. The script was really bad. I knew right away it was not going to be a solid pick, since the pacing almost felt like a Lifetime holiday film on a bad acid trip. The three listed above did their best with what they were given, especially Mulroney, but man, the direction and those horrible lines! Not to mention the plot holes were crater-sized and many of the characters' actions were implausible to anyone with common sense...and I have quite an imagination and can still not see anything like this going down in any circumstances. What was with the bra shopping? "Oh, hi, I am your brand new boss, but I am going to take you bra shopping and GO IN THE DRESSING ROOM WITH YOU." Such a natural unfolding of events we have all experienced at sometime, amirite? Some other highlights include twin kids that look completely different ages, horrible acting by some secondary actors, a psychiatric disorder many doctors deny exist and a storyline that defies logic in any universe. I mean, where did the extra bike come from? If she "hadn't done this in a long time" (as in, riding a bike), why did she have a brand new adult bike just sitting around ready for them to go on a long, sensual ride to the lake (where they had a full spread with wine yet no character was seen going or coming back with any supplies)? It's little things like that, over and over again that just makes the viewer wish they had bowel problems so they could take a bathroom break to avoid another scene. Just don't watch it. It will make you depressed that actors like these are taking on projects like this. I was debating a 1, but gave it a 2 since you do get to see Mulroney's bare ass and that is never disagreeable as far as I am concerned. But someone's going to be up for a Razzie for this excrement and it will be well deserved. I wish Netflix refunded money for things they say are "#3 watched in the nation" but suck this bad. It's uncool to set viewers up like that.

Review title: In someone else's hands it could have been so much better
Review_body: The story, had it been executed by an accomplished director, could have been amazing. My take on this is that Mary has an alter ego. All the books she has written before are violent and this perhaps is her outlet to remain *normal* on the outside. But since we are seeing everything from Mary's POV we have to ultimately conclude that there IS NO GRACE. Mary is Grace. Through creating this character, a younger version of Mary who possibly was abused as a child herself, she is able to break free from her writer's block and function as a person. The end scene is confusing. She is wearing the same headscarf and coat that was seen on footage of the woman who slashed the throat of Mary's best friend, Elaine. So who is that person leaving the hospital after visiting Grace? I am not sure why the director left us guessing like this. I am also uncomfortable when mental illness is used as a vector to spread disinformation about people who suffer mentally. In the 1960s there was a film TWISTED NERVE that had an insane man commit gross murders. But he happened to have a younger brother with Downs Syndrome. The film alluded to the fact that this murderer had a damaged gene in his family. And Downs Syndrome was the connection. This is lazy and sloppy. I think Deadly Illusions fell into the same trap. I would have liked to have seen an intelligent portrayal of a deeply disturbed woman.

In summary it's essentially a modern day remake of The Hand That Rocks The Cradle, an early 90's film that was good for its time. They've altered some aspects to modernise it, like make the live-in babysitters obsession with the mother become sexual, in addition to it being sexual with the husband. But otherwise it wanders no further from the hackneyed plot of "obsessed outsider infiltrates and ruins family".
It's one of those films that I think people in the industry still think they're right when they have meetings around tables and say things to each other like "We're gonna show people how wealthy this family is because people love seeing opulence!" When in actual fact that approach is dated and considered very unrelatable these days.
It kind of attempts to make you wonder whether the main female character or the babysitter character is the one causing the problems. But it just comes across as muddled and unclear. You get what might be flashbacks, might be memories, or visions from the main character of both herself and the babysitter doing terrible things, because apparently she "gets very dark" when she's writing... yawn. She gets so dark she randomly goes completely mental, dropping the f-bomb at the dining room table in front of her kids, after no hint whatsoever that she was about to lose the plot. And everyone reacts... as if it's fairly normal.
Sadly this film suffers far too much from those annoying experiences viewers have, such as saying to him/herself "You wouldn't do that / say that." Or "Why did she do / say that?" many times throughout the film.
Ultimately, it bears little resemblance to normal people and normal everyday life, which is a shame because it's a straight up drama based on earth in 2021...

The more absurd the plot gets they more the actors seem to with draw from their roles, like they really just don't care about putting the effort in anymore. The main actresses performances in particular go from good to desperately bad. From an action point no of the hits have impact, even the really violent scene are just so uneventful and you don't have much reason to care for the characters.In the end, the exploitative portrayal of dissociative identity disorder and the inclusion of a child abuse plot, which closely resembles the Turpin case to an uncomfortable degree, were the final nail in the coffin for this film. Review title: Once again a movie that spreads misinformation by claiming DID/schizophrenia = killer, disappointing
Review_body: I was intrigued by the idea of the movie at first but the further it got, the worse it got. In the end it is revealed that Grace is traumatized and therefore "of course" becomes an insane killer. I am genuinely angry that mental illnesses like schizophrenia and DID keep getting portrayed like something that makes a person dangerous. This kind of "person ends up hurting others"-stuff happens extremely rarely and people who suffer from these mental conditions will probably feel extremely uncomfortable about discussing them because WELL MOVIES LIKE THIS. Using mental illnesses and the incredibly misinformed stereotypes surrounding them as a way to make money is just plain stupid, especially when a movie where these would be corrected would most likely create a much better, well, movie.Also, the movie made it look like she was able to control her transformations, which is ridiculous, it's not like an on/off-switch you press. It happens through triggers. And she seemed to be able to hide the other personality of hers which, once again is completely unrealistic.The ending was confusing and the point where she walks out of the hospital is in my opinion completely unnecessary. I doubt anyone liked that part simply because it was such an obvious "mysterious ending oooo". I would have been a lot less disappointed if the movie had ended when they met each other at the hospital -- at least that would've indicated that Grace got help for her untreated illness.

Review title: One of the Worst Movies I Have Watched
Review_body: This movie has to be one of the worst I have ever watched. The plot itself sounded promising, but the execution is awful. First of all, both the acting and script are cringeworthy. The script contains dialogue that no one would say in real life. Next, the plot contains major holes. Grace's motivations for killing off the family are never revealed, besides the fact that she says she is "insane." Also, the children are absent for the majority of the movie when Grace was hired to be their caregiver. Lastly, my major bone to pick with this movie is its portrayal of DID, previously known as split personality. This movie further perpetuates the stereotypes associated with DID and continues to stigmatize the mental health disorder. The movie continues the harmful narrative that individuals with DID are "crazy" and prone to violent outbursts. In conclusion, not only does this movie contain terrible acting, cringeworthy dialogue, major plot holes, but it continues to demonize a real mental health disorder.

Husband "makes a bad trade" that you never know anything about and it's implied he loses half their money, though they are rich. You never see a lifestyle change or anything else come of this. This is revealed in a 2 minute scene on their patio and it's just over. 3. Kristin Davis has to write a new book now so she interviews nannies for a while until Greer Grammer shows up and gets the job. She spends the entire movie shopping and doing weird activities with the parents who never seem to spend any time with their kids. 4. Davis spends the whole movie telling everyone how "weird" she gets when she writes and you're not supposed to be able to tell if she's going crazy or if her affairs with Grammer are real or not. 5. Davis magically finds a family member of Greer two hours away and gets a dumb little traumatic backstory out of nowhere. 6. Davis' best friend is murdered, they think Davis did it but she can't be sure because she's sO cRaZy WhEn ShE WrItEs. 7. Greer is mentally ill and tries to murder the couple and locks the kids in a bedroom. 8. Davis wins the fight and Greer gets sent to an institution, but they're still friends and Davis visits her. Nothing. Interesting. Happens.

That's why the babysitter is such a clean type, called Grace, her age sometimes 20 but sometimes 40. She also is the main character of her new book. Things get messy. Keys to understand are scattered around in the movie, but it just never becomes clear for most viewers. The note about her illness, the slit wheel, her visit to Grace's schizophrenic relative etc. It would have been a more helpful ending to understand, if at the end she would visited 'Grace', they would played cards but looking into the room we would only have seen Mary. The psychological hell of all the suspicions and doubts about hiring the perfect and pretty young nanny begin to arise. The low reveiwers, (not unlike anyone who falls unawares into mentally troubled waters) are titalated yet frustrated, just don't follow the pure, wordless dipiction of descent into mental illness.
